questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures: posterior surface of the navicular, anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The neovascularization arises from the optic nerve head; there is neovascularization of the disc (NVD) and along the large vessels, as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty holding his limb close to his chest and unable to complete the range of motion. He was trying to break open a locked door with his shoulder. His vitals are otherwise stable. X-ray shows anterior dislocation of his shoulder joint. Which of the following methods cannot be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
All of the given options are the methods used for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation, except Sushruta's method.

Anterior dislocation is the commonest shoulder dislocation and can be caused due to trauma from behind the shoulder pushing the head out anteriorly. It is also caused due to falling on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. It can be diagnosed on clinical examination with flattening of the shoulder contour and ability to place a rule (Hamilton ruler test) and the inability to touch his/her opposite shoulder (Duga's test). X-ray confirms the diagnosis and may show associated Hill Sachs or bony bankart lesion. The most common complication is a recurrent shoulder dislocation.

It can be adequately treated by prompt reduction by any of the described methods.

The image shows common associated Xray findings in anterior shoulder lesion. 

Hill Sach's lesion is due to impingement of glenoid labrum into the humeral head, causing posterolateral depression.

Bankart lesion is due to stripping of the glenoid labrum from the glenoid cavity as the head dislocates. It sometimes may be associated with bony avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid rim as seen in this image.

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle overpressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time. In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callaway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method- Surgeon applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with a large, rapidly-progressing abdominal mass, lymphadenopathy and ascites. He was suggested prophylactic therapy to prevent spread to the CNS. A lymph node biopsy given below shows two different cell populations labeled A & B .  Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It can present with three distinct clinical forms
It is a  very rapidly proliferating human tumor
Tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20,  CD10 and BCL2 but negative for BCL6.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the starry-sky appearance on the lymph node biopsy are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. In the given biopsy specimen, "A" indicates the reactive macrophages and "B" represents the tumour cells (B cells). Tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10 and BCL6 but negative for BCL2.

  • The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with frequent mitotic figures - an indication of high growth fraction.  
  • Reactive macrophages are scattered throughout the tumour and their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumour cells gives the tumor a so-called starry sky appearance. Reactive leukocytes and macrophages are not stained by special stains. 

The growth fraction of these lymphomas is very high, with frequent mitotic figures being seen and the fraction of Ki-67+ (MIB-1+) cells approaching 100%.

Related Pearl: Burkitt Lymphoma

 

  • It is the most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Burkitt's leukemia (Bone marrow involvement) is ALL-L3 .It is associated with c-myc dysregulation.
  •  Important translocations are: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated
    • Sporadic: in adults in western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • Most patients present with peripheral lymphadenopathy and intrabdominal mass and it rapidly progresses and metastasize to CNS.
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells .
  • Histology: Starry sky pattern
  • Immunophenotype: 
    • The tumor cells express  B cell-associated antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a), germinal center-associated markers (CD10 & BCL-6), & CD43. BCL-2 may be present in upto 20%. 
    • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on EBV status of the tumors.
      • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
      • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression
  • Treatment:
    • Begins immediately after the diagnosis in both children and adults with the use of an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide
    • Prophylactic therapy to the CNS is mandatory
  • Cure rate is 70-80% (good prognosis)

questions.text: All are true about the condition given below in the image except that_____.

choices.text: It affects  thickening in medium and large muscular arteries.
“String of beads” appearance is seen on angiography.
It is associated with the use of oral contraceptives.

questions.solution:
The given image shows 'string of beads' appearance of vessels on angiography suggesting the diagnosis of Fibromuscular dysplasia . Although fibromuscular dysplasia is seen most frequently in young women, there is no association with oral contraceptives or increased estrogen expression.

  • Fibromuscular dysplasia is a focal irregular thickening in medium and large muscular arteries, involves renal, carotid, splanchnic, and vertebral vessels.
  • The cause is probably developmental.
  • First-degree relatives of affected individuals have an increased incidence.
  • Segments of the vessel wall are focally thickened by a combination of medial and intimal hyperplasia and fibrosis, resulting in luminal stenosis.
  • In the renal arteries, this can be a cause of renovascular hypertension.
  • On angiography, the vessels are said to have a “string of beads” appearance.

questions.text:
Among the following antitubercular drugs given below, which of the following drugs have a bactericidal action?
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Rifampicin
  3. Pyrazinamide
  4. Ethambutol
  5. Streptomycin
questions.solution:
Ethambutol (E) is the only bacteriostatic agent among the given options. All the options are examples of bactericidal drugs. Therefore, option 4(A, B, C, E) is the right answer

Bactericidal antituberculosis agents (RIPS)

  • R: Rifampicin (R)
  • I: Isoniazid (H)
  • P: Pyrazinamide (Z)
  • S: Streptomycin (S)

Treatment regimens for pulmonary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis consist of an initial 2-month phase of a 4-drug regimen, followed by a continuation phase of an additional 4 months of isoniazid and rifampin for pulmonary tuberculosis.

Isoniazid: is used for the treatment of tuberculosis (as part of combination therapy) or for latent tuberculosis infection (as monotherapy or part of combination therapy). The antimicrobial activity of INH is selective for mycobacteria, likely due to its ability to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis, which interferes with cell wall synthesis, thereby producing a bactericidal effect 

Rifampicin: is thought to inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which appears to occur as a result of drug binding in the polymerase subunit deep within the DNA/RNA channel, facilitating direct blocking of the elongating RNA. Along with Isoniazid, Rifampicin is also given in both initial phase and continuation phase of treatment of TB.

Pyrazinamide: most commonly used for the treatment of active tuberculosis (TB) during the initial phase of therapy only(generally the first two months of treatment), in combination with other agents. The spectrum of PZA is relatively narrow; it demonstrates clinically significant antibacterial activity only against Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium africanum.

Streptomycin: injectable drug, also a bactericidal drug used sometimes in the initial phase of treatment of pulmonary TB.

Ethambutol: The only drug in the initial phase which is an example of a bacteriostatic drug. There is evidence that the drug exerts its bacteriostatic activity by virtue of inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme that polymerizes arabinose into arabinan and then arabinogalactan, a mycobacterial cell wall constituent

Related Pearl: General properties of the first line drugs in TB

First-line drugs
Isoniazid
Rifampicin
Pyrazinamide
Ethambutol
Mechanism
Bactericidal
Bactericidal
(Maximum)
Bactericidal
Bacteriostatic
Location of Mycobacteria
Intracellular +  Extracellular
Intracellular +  Extracellular
Intracellular
Extracellular
Metabolism
Liver
Liver
(Maximum)
Liver
Kidney

 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug ResistantTB regimen

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

H: Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown / undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: Lemierre’s disease is a life-threatening condition of the head and neck that is most commonly associated with which of the following anaerobes?
questions.solution:
• Fusobacterium necrophorum
    • It is a Gram-negative anaerobic bacillus which is very pleomorphic.
    • It is involved in very severe oropharyngeal infections, one which is the complicated and life-threatening Lemierre’s disease.
  • Lemierre’s disease
    • It is also called postanginal septicemia and commonly occurs after infectious mononucleosis.
    • It is mostly seen in children and young adults.
    • This complicated infection of the head and neck usually starts with a sore throat which progresses to become very severe.
    • Septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein develops after the infection by F. necrophorum spreads into the lateral pharyngeal space.
    • This causes dysphagia, severe pain, neck swelling and stiffness.
    • The disease can progress to sepsis and metastatic infection of the lung and other sites. Mediastinitis or erosion of the carotid artery can also occur as the disease progresses.
    • Treatment includes IV antibiotics usually clindamycin or ampicillin/sulbactam and surgical drainage of purulent collections.

Clinical case: A 17 year-old student develops infectious mononucleosis. About 15 days later, he develops a higher fever and his sore throat worsens. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. In this case, the organism that is most likely to be causing this complication is Fusobacterium necrophorum.

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for:
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Veress Needle. It is used to produce a pneumoperitoneum.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating a towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures.

questions.text: Your co-intern requests the unit chief for leave for this weekend, which is denied by the chief. However, on Saturday morning, your co-intern complains of severe pain in the abdomen and seeks medical care. Physical examination reveals no abnormality and USG abnormality shows a normal study. Further investigations do not reveal an organic cause. Which of the following should be considered?
questions.solution:
The scenario described is suggestive of malingering.

In the given scenario it is important to find out whether the patient has a motive for feigning symptoms. Intentional production of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve some practical gain (e.g. financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility or military service, leave from work) is suggestive of malingering. In the given scenario, the patient falsely complained of abdominal pain, to avail leave from work, hence malingering should be considered. 

Other options:

Option b: Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome) is the intentional production of physical symptoms to obtain medical attention, not a practical gain.

Option c: Somatic symptom disorder, also called hypochondriasis, is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation for 6 or more months, with fears of having, or the idea that one has, a serious disease based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option d: Dissociative fugue refers to sudden travel away from home associated with partial or complete memory loss about one's identity.

questions.text:
Match the following weapons with their possible injury type:
A. Axe 1. Incised wound
B. RTA 2. Tram track bruise
C. Blade 3. Grazed abrasion
D. Lathi 4. Chop wound
questions.solution:
For the above-given weapons, possible injury type is matched as under:

A. Axe 4. Chop wounds
B. RTA 3. Graze abrasions
C. Blade 1. Incised wound
D. Lathi 2. Tram track bruise

Mechanism of injury with the above weapons

Axe - it is a heavy weapon that may or may not be sharpened. Injury is produced by chopping action of the weapon and it may be in a spectrum of an incised wound to laceration depending upon the sharpness of the blade.

RTA - rubbing of epidermis tangential to a rough or hard surface gives rise to graze abrasion also called brush burn. It can occur in an RTA after a pedestrian is being hit by a vehicle and the victim is slid/grazed for some distance before he comes to a halt.

Blade - it gives rise to a clean-cut wound which is usually deepest at its starting. Tailing of the wound indicates the direction of injury. Length is the biggest parameter of this type of wound.

Lathi- It is a blunt force injury giving rise to a patterned abrasion with 2 parallel lines and a normal unbruised area on site of impact or stick/lathi. The lathi forces the blood from the site of impact to either side which gives rise to tramline appearance.

The above image shows a chop wound inflicted on scalp.

The above image shows a schematic illustrating heaping up of epidermis in a graze abrasion or brush burn

The above image shows production of a tramline bruise associated with a lathi strike

questions.text: The baby is in which station?
questions.solution:
The head of the fetus it at the level of ischial spines. So it is in station 0.

  • The fetal station, that is the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal, is described in relation to the ischial spines. These spines lie halfway between the pelvic inlet and the pelvic outlet. When the lowermost portion of the presenting fetal part is at the level of the ischial spines, it is designated to be in zero station.
  • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines the designation is -5,-4, -3,-2,-1 then 0 station.
  • Below the spines, the presenting part passes +1,+2,+3,+4,+5 stations. Station +5 corresponds to the fetal head is visible at the level of introitus.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow, and his urine appears pale straw. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase.

Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 hours and/or treatment with phototherapy without cessation of breastfeeding. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Other options: 

Option A and D: Biliary atresia and Neonatal cholestasis have conjugated bilirubinemia.

Option C: Erythroblastosis foetalis has unconjugated bilirubinemia and it is seen in the first 24 hours of life.

questions.text: A patient presents with Fever with chills and Rigors. He gives a history of swelling of the right eye that has now spread to the left eye as well. All this was preceded by a ‘Boil’ over the philtrum over a week back. Which of the following is not a finding you would expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of Cavernous sinus thrombosis. Mydriasis, not miosis, would be the expected finding here.

Cavernous Sinus thrombosis affects III, IV and VI Cranial nerves.

CN III involvement results in Ptosis and Mydriasis.

CN VI involvement results in Lateral Gaze Palsy.

CN IV is the last to be involved which together with the above lesions result in complete ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images are suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage shaped mass in longitudinal plane or a target mass in transverse plane  on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Other options:

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea and/or vomiting. It shows coffee bean sign.

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa.

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis.

questions.text: Identify the enzyme that synthesizes galactose from glucose:
questions.solution:
Galactose can be synthesiszed from glucose by the enzyme UDPGal 4-epimerase. Hence, galactose is not an essential dietary carbohydrate. Galactose is required for the formation of lactose in lactation and is also a constituent of cerebrosides, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins.

Other options:

  • Lactose synthase forms lactose from glucose and galactose.
  • Phosphoglucomutase interconverts between glucose-6-phosphate and glucose-1-phosphate
  • Aldolase A & C preferentially cleave fructose–1,6 bisphosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate. Aldolase B cleaves fructose-1 phosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde.
